label: Self Efficacy Multiplier
hover description: If you feel confident to make dietary changes, you are also more likely to shift toward sustainable eating habits. Self Efficacy refers to an individual's belief in their ability to successfully adopt and maintain a different diet.

label: Response Efficacy Multiplier
hover description: If you trust that your actions have impact, you are more likely to change your behavior. Response Efficacy reflects the belief that adopting a different diet will effectively contribute to positive environmental or health outcomes.

label: Perceived Risks Multiplier
hover description: If you perceive greater risks from the environment, you may be more likely to adopt dietary changes. Perceived Risks is affected by both the sensitivity towards extreme events but also its frequency.

label: Perceived Risks (No Education)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate NoEd Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Primary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Primary Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Secondary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Secondary Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Tertiary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Tertiary Variation

label: Social Norms Multiplier
hover description: If sustainable eating is widely accepted among your friends, you are also more likely to adopt such diets. Social Norms refer to the influence of societal and peer expectations on an individual's diet choices.

label: Conventional Diet Compositions
hover description: This is the assumed diet of the global population that maintains traditional eating habits.

label: Start Year
varname: Start Year of Meat Diet Switch
hover description: This slider controls the start and end year of the food waste scenario, assuming that changes will follow an S-shaped curve.

label: End Year
varname: End Year of Meat Diet Switch

label: Alternative Diet Compositions
hover description: This is the assumed diet of the global population that deviates from mainstream eating habits, often for health, ethical, or cultural reasons.

label: Start Year
varname: Start Year of Vegetarian Diet Switch
hover description: This slider controls the start and end year of the food waste scenario, assuming that changes will follow an S-shaped curve.

label: End Year
varname: End Year of Vegetarian Diet Switch

label: Start Year
hover description: This slider controls the start and end year of the food waste scenario, assuming that changes will follow an S-shaped curve.

label: Pasture Meat
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[PasMeat]
hover description: Meat from animals raised on grasslands, such as beef and lamb. These meats have a higher environmental impact due to land and water use.

label: Crop Meat
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[CropMeat]
hover description: Meat from animals primarily fed on crops like soy and corn, including chicken and pork. Generally, they have a lower footprint than pasture meats.

label: Dairy
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Dairy]
hover description: Products made from milk, such as cheese, yogurt, and butter. Dairy farming contributes to greenhouse gas emissions and water usage.

label: Eggs
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Eggs]
hover description: A nutrient-rich food source from poultry, including chicken, duck, and quail eggs. Lower environmental impact compared to meat but still requires feed and water.

label: Pulses
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Pulses]
hover description: Protein-rich plant foods like lentils, beans, and chickpeas. They improve soil health and have a low carbon footprint.

label: Grains
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Grains]
hover description: Staple crops such as wheat, rice, corn, and oats. Widely consumed and essential for global food security, but some require high water usage.

label: Vegetables and Fruits
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[VegFruits]
hover description: A diverse group including leafy greens, root vegetables, and berries. Generally have a lower environmental impact, but factors like transport and refrigeration matter.

label: Other Crops
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[OtherCrops]
hover description: Includes foods like nuts, sugar, coffee, and oils (palm, soybean, canola). Some have significant land-use impacts, especially tropical crops like palm oil.

label: Consumption
hover description: Food wasted at the consumer level, including leftovers, spoiled groceries, and plate waste in households, restaurants, and cafeterias.

label: Processing
hover description: Losses during food manufacturing, such as trimming, discarded ingredients, and overproduction in factories producing packaged foods.

label: Distribution
hover description: Waste occurring during transport and retail, including damaged packaging, expired goods, and rejected produce due to appearance standards.

label: Primary Production
hover description: Losses at the farm level, such as crops left unharvested, damage from pests/weather, and overproduction leading to food being plowed under.

label: Post Harvest
hover description: Waste occurring after harvesting but before processing or retail, including improper storage, spoilage, and losses in drying or transport.
